H0.text: Calculator is the most likely way a scientist collects data during an experiment.

H1.text: Graphs are the most likely way a scientist collects data during an experiment.

H2.text: Observations are the most likely way a scientist collects data during an experiment.

H3.text: A computer is the most likely way a scientist collects data during an experiment.

A4.text: Scientific measurements are usually tabulated, graphed, or mapped

A5.text: The measurements might be made in a controlled setting, such as a laboratory, or made on more or less inaccessible or unmanipulatable objects such as stars or human populations

A6.text: Natural experiments rely solely on observations of the variables of the system under study

A7.text: The degree to which this is possible depends on the observed correlation between explanatory variables in the observed data
